questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever and dull right upper quadrant pain for the past week. Two months ago, he returned from a vacation in Mexico. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. He does not take any medication and has not been exposed to any sick contacts. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 86/min, blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies are shown below. An abdominal CT shows a single round mass with an enhancing solid rim and central complex fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

 White Blood Cells      12x103/µL    
 Neutrophils     40%    
 Hemoglobin     14.0 g/dL anemia    
 Hematocrit     42%    
 Platelets     350x103/µL normal    
 Aspartate aminotransferase     110/L    
 Alanine aminotransferase     105/L    
 Alkaline Phosphatase      100/L    
 Bilirubin      1.1 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a week of fever and right upper quadrant pain after a trip to Mexico two months ago. He has right upper quadrant tenderness and hepatomegaly on exam and laboratory studies show elevated LFTs with an elevated WBC without a left shift and normal bilirubin. Abdominal CT reveals a single rounded mass with an enhancing solid rim and central complex fluid. These findings are consistent with an amebic liver abscess. 

When evaluating liver lesions, it is important to quickly determine whether the lesion is benign or infectious and requires immediate treatment, or malignant and requires further diagnostic evaluation. A focused history and physical exam followed by labwork, including serologies, and contrast-enhanced imaging can help make the diagnosis of infectious liver pathologies. These can include amebic abscesses, pyogenic abscesses, and echinococcal cysts. Patients with any of these lesions should be admitted to the hospital and treated appropriately. Treatment can involve medical management, aspiration, and surgery, depending on the type of infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pyogenic liver abscess:
Incorrect: Pyogenic liver abscesses typically occur in older patients after multiple hepatobiliary infections with bowel leakage and peritonitis. Patients typically have hyperbilirubinemia. This patient’s travel history, lab work, and CT findings are more consistent with amebic liver abscess.  
❌ Echinococcal hepatic cyst :
Incorrect: Echinococcal hepatic cysts occur in patients who have recently traveled to endemic areas, such as Central or South America. Most patients are asymptomatic until the cyst grows large enough to have a mass effect and cause abdominal discomfort and right upper quadrant pain. CT typically shows a large, well-defined, unilocular or multilocular liver cyst with multiple internal “daughter” cysts.  
✅ Amebic liver abscess :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Simple Cyst :
Incorrect: Simple cysts are small and benign, and only produce symptoms (e.g., right upper quadrant pain) if they become enlarged. Laboratory studies are typically normal, and constitutional signs and symptoms (e.g., fever, chills, diarrhea) are absent.  
❌ Focal nodular hyperplasia  :
Incorrect: Focal nodular hyperplasia is a benign liver lesion made up of hyperplastic hepatocytes surrounding a central stellate scar. Most patients are asymptomatic and have normal liver function studies. This patient's elevated LFTs, symptomatology, and CT findings are more consistent with amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder, fever reaching 38.6°C (101.5°F), and shortness of breath. He has not had jaundice, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy four weeks ago for acute cholecystitis. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 113/73 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.  On physical examination, the patient has tenderness in the right upper quadrant and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with a left shift and an elevated CRP. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast
Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage with fluid cultures

questions.solution:
This patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy four days ago and is presenting with RUQ abdominal pain, shoulder pain, fever, dyspnea, decreased breath sounds in the right lung base, and elevated inflammatory markers. These findings are suggestive of a subphrenic abscess caused by recent abdominal surgery. The most appropriate next step in evaluating a suspected subphrenic abscess in this patient is to confirm the diagnosis with a CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast. CT is the best imaging for detecting left-sided subphrenic abscesses and all other intra-abdominal abscesses. Abdominal ultrasound can also be used to diagnose right-sided subphrenic abscesses.

On a CT scan, an intra-abdominal abscess appears as an intra-abdominal fluid collection outside the bowel lumen with possible contrast-enhancing rim, bubbles, or air-fluid levels. Once the diagnosis of intra-abdominal abscess has been made, complicating features on imaging should be assessed to determine the management approach. The presence of one or more of the following features is considered a complicating feature:

  • Percutaneously inaccessible abscess
  • Poorly localized or multifocal abscess
  • High-density fluid indicating hematoma
  • Multi-loculated abscess
  • Presence of anastomotic leak
  • Presence of free hollow organ perforation

If an anastomotic leak or free hollow organ perforation is also seen, the patient will likely have signs of peritonitis and an acute abdomen with diffuse abdominal tenderness, abdominal rigidity, and rebound and guarding. An emergent surgical consult should be called in these cases.
 


Option Analysis

✅ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Correct: See the main explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage with fluid cultures:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. Ultrasound-guided percutaneous drainage may be used to treat a subphrenic abscess and to determine the pathologic cause; however, diagnosis with CT should be made first.  
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. A radiograph is not as sensitive as CT for diagnosing subphrenic abscesses, and often the only finding seen on a plain radiograph is an elevated hemidiaphragm. Gas or pleural effusions may also be seen on radiography.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical picture is consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. While obtaining blood cultures is essential in managing a suspected subphrenic abscess, it is not the best initial step for making the diagnosis. Diagnosis should be made with CT of the abdomen and pelvis, blood cultures should be sent, and empiric antibiotics should be started.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP):
Incorrect: ERCP is an important diagnostic and therapeutic tool used for managing biliary tract disorders (e.g., cholangitis, choledocholithiasis, and biliary stricture). However, this patient has had a cholecystectomy and his presentation is more consistent with a right-sided subphrenic abscess. CT of the abdomen and pelvis should be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for the past 12-hours. The abdominal pain was initially dull and diffuse but subsequently progressed to a sharp pain in the right lower abdomen. Medical history is significant for epilepsy and asthma. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. Physical examination reveals right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with a leftwards shift. An abdominal CT scan is notable for a distended and edematous appendix with surrounding soft tissue stranding. Emergent surgery under general anesthesia is scheduled. Which one of the following anesthetic agents is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute appendicitis, and an emergency appendectomy is planned under general anesthesia. Enflurane is contraindicated in this patient, given her history of epilepsy.

Inhaled anesthetics include nitrous oxide, which acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist, and halogenated anesthetics (e.g., halothane, enflurane, methoxyflurane, desflurane), that act as NMDA receptor antagonists and GABA receptor agonists.

Inhaled anesthetics can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression,  respiratory depression, increased cerebral blood flow, and increased intracranial pressure. They also blunt the sympathetic response to hypoxia, so monitoring arterial oxygen saturation after administering these medications is essential. Other side effects include hepatotoxicity (halothane), nephrotoxicity (methoxyflurane), lowered seizure threshold (enflurane), and expansion of trapped gas within body cavities (nitric oxide).

All halogenated anesthetics can cause a life-threatening condition called malignant hyperthermia. The anesthetic agents cause an increased release of calcium stored in muscle cells, resulting in relentless muscle contractions and heat generation. Symptoms of malignant hyperthermia include muscle rigidity, rhabdomyolysis, hyperthermia, metabolic acidosis, and tachycardia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is a parenteral anesthetic that potentiates the effects of GABAA on its receptors. It can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression, and propofol infusion syndrome. However, this patient has no contraindications to propofol administration.  
❌ Methoxyflurane:
Incorrect: Methoxyflurane is known to cause nephrotoxicity in susceptible individuals. It is not contraindicated in patients with epilepsy or asthma.  
✅ Enflurane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Halothane:
Incorrect: Halothane is an anesthetic. Halothane dilates the airways so that it can be used in patients with asthma. However, it is no longer used in developed countries since it can cause severe and potentially fatal hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: Ketamine is a parenteral anesthetic that blocks NMDA receptors. It is known to stimulate the sympathetic nervous system and cause dissociative amnesia. However, it can be safely used in patients with epilepsy and asthma.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening left lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and constipation. She has not had nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Past medical history is significant for uncomplicated acute diverticulitis, diagnosed and managed conservatively six weeks ago. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. On examination, the patient has tenderness in the left lower quadrant with guarding. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen reveals a 5 cm uniloculated, well-localized abscess in the left lower quadrant adjacent to a segment of inflamed diverticula. IV access is obtained, fluids are started, and blood cultures are taken. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start empiric antibiotics and consult interventional radiology for image-guided percutaneous drainage
Start empiric antibiotics and consult surgery for surgical drainage
Start empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of acute diverticulitis presents with LLQ abdominal pain, fever, elevated inflammatory markers, and a uniloculated, well-localized 5 cm abscess adjacent to inflamed diverticula on a CT scan. These findings are consistent with an intra-abdominal abscess without complicating features. The most appropriate next step in managing a hemodynamically stable patient with an accessible large intra-abdominal abscess without complicating features is to perform image-guided percutaneous drainage.

The initial treatment of an intra-abdominal abscess depends on several factors, including the patient's hemodynamic stability, the size and accessibility of the abscess for percutaneous drainage, and the presence or absence of complicating features on imaging.

Percutaneous drainage is recommended for managing accessible intra-abdominal abscesses 3 cm or larger without complicating features. In contrast, surgical drainage, including open or laparoscopic approaches, is typically used for treating abscesses with complicating features where percutaneous drainage is not feasible, contraindicated, or fails to resolve the abscess. An emergent laparotomy is indicated if the patient exhibits bowel perforation, anastomosis leak, ischemia, or hemodynamic instability.

Antibiotic therapy should be tailored based on the patient's clinical response and pathogens. Empiric antibiotics should target common intra-abdominal pathogens, such as gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic bacteria. They should be used alongside percutaneous or surgical drainage to eradicate infection. Rarely, if the abscess is smaller than three centimeters, treatment with IV antibiotics is possible.

Option Analysis

✅ Start empiric antibiotics and consult interventional radiology for image-guided percutaneous drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start empiric antibiotics and consult surgery for surgical drainage:
Incorrect: Surgical drainage is typically reserved for abscesses with complicating features (e.g., percutaneously inaccessible, poorly localized, multifocal, high-density fluid, multi-loculated) and abscesses not responding to other management. In this case, the abscess is well-localized, uniloculated, and accessible for percutaneous drainage, making it the preferred management approach.  
❌ Start empiric IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation:
Incorrect: Although initiation of empiric antibiotics and hospital admission are essential components of managing this patient, they are not sufficient treatment of this abscess that is 5 centimeters. Image-guided percutaneous drainage is required to facilitate adequate drainage and resolution of the infection.  
❌ Consult surgery for emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: Emergent laparotomy is reserved for patients with hemodynamic instability, diffuse peritonitis, or high suspicion of bowel perforation or anastomosis leak. In this patient, the abscess is well-localized and accessible for percutaneous drainage, making laparotomy unnecessary.  
❌ Perform serial abdominal examinations:
Incorrect: Serial abdominal exams alone do not appropriately manage a 5 cm, localized intra-abdominal abscess. Empiric antibiotics and image-guided percutaneous drainage are required to facilitate treatment, adequate drainage, and infection eradication.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain to the emergency department. The symptoms developed five hours and have progressively worsened. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 139/77 mmHg, and pulse is 98/min. Physical examination reveals rebound tenderness with guarding in the right lower quadrant. She undergoes a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis and is found to have acute perforated appendicitis. The patient is provided with fentanyl for analgesia before being transported to the operating room. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist
κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist

questions.solution:
The opioid receptor agonists list is exhaustive, but commonly administered medications include fentanyl, morphine, hydromorphone, and hydrocodone. Unlike partial agonists and mixed opiate agonists/antagonists, full agonists are used purely for analgesic effects.    

In contrast, partial agonists like buprenorphine carry analgesic properties but are also used for maintenance therapy to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opioid use disorder. Mixed opiate agonists/antagonists are primarily used to treat severe pain but have less respiratory depression when compared to full opiate agonists.    

Recalling which medications fall under each class is an essential concept for Step 1 and Step 2.  



Option Analysis

✅ μ-opioid receptor agonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ μ-opioid receptor partial agonism:
Incorrect: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist of the μ-opioid receptor. This medication is used to prevent relapse in patients with chronic opioid use disorder.   
❌ μ-opioid receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the effects of naloxone, a full μ-opioid receptor antagonist. This medication is used to reverse acute opioid intoxication.   
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor partial agonist:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of butorphanol. In contrast, fentanyl works by acting as a full μ-opioid receptor agonist.  
❌ κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor antagonist or partial agonist  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of pentazocine. In contrast, this patient was administered fentanyl, which works by acting as a full μ-opioid receptor agonist.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of moderate Crohn disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, fever, and chills for the past three days. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg, pulse is 106/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a soft abdomen with tenderness to palpation in the right lower quadrant. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. Laboratory findings show a white blood cell count of 16,000/µL. Blood cultures are drawn. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a two-centimeter uniloculated abscess in the ileocecal region. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation
Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and perform surgical drainage
Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and perform CT-guided drainage

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a three-day history of abdominal pain, fever, tachycardia in the context of moderate Crohn's disease. Evaluation reveals leukocytosis and a two-centimeter uniloculated intra-abdominal abscess in the ileocecal region. These findings are consistent with  an uncomplicated intra-abdominal abscess. This patient should be managed with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and close monitoring in the intensive care unit. If the patient responds to these measures, drainage may not be necessary for this small (less than two centimeters) abscess.

When managing an adult with an intra-abdominal abscess, the first step is to address the patient's hemodynamic status. This includes administering IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic organisms. In addition to hemodynamic support, image-guided or surgical drainage of the abscess may be indicated depending on the size and accessibility of the abscess and the presence of complicating features on imaging. Abscesses three-six centimeters without complicating features on imaging should be managed with image-guided percutaneous drainage. In contrast, abscesses with complicating features on imaging should be handled with surgical drainage.

Patients with signs and symptoms of diffuse peritonitis, such as severe diffuse abdominal tenderness with rigidity, rebound, and guarding, or imaging findings consistent with perforation require emergent exploratory laparotomy for diagnosis and treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and admit to the intensive care unit for observation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and perform surgical drainage:
Incorrect: Surgical drainage is typically reserved for abscesses with complicating features (e.g., percutaneously inaccessible, poorly localized, multifocal, high-density fluid, multi-loculated) and abscesses not responding to other management. In this case, the abscess is well-localized, uniloculated, and less than three centimeters; it can be managed initially with IV antibiotics and close follow-up.  
❌ Initiate broad-spectrum IV empiric antibiotics and perform CT-guided drainage:
Incorrect: Although broad-spectrum IV antibiotics are essential to treat this patient’s intra-abdominal abscess, CT-guided drainage is typically used to treat uncomplicated intra-abdominal abscesses three-six centimeters in size. IV broad-spectrum antibiotics with close monitoring in the ICU is the best next step in managing this stable patient.  
❌ Perform emergent laparotomy:
Incorrect: Emergent laparotomy is indicated for patients with diffuse peritonitis or concern for bowel perforation or ischemia. This patient's abscess size and location do not warrant an invasive intervention as the first step in treatment.  
❌ Perform urgent colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Urgent colonoscopy is not indicated in this situation, as it does not address the intra-abdominal abscess. Furthermore, a colonoscopy in a patient with severe acute inflammation and possible bowel wall compromise may increase the risk of perforation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a four-day history of worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain that radiates to the right flank and the groin. The patient underwent an appendectomy for a perforated appendix two weeks ago. He reports a fever reaching 38.4°C (101.1°F) and has noticed a decrease in appetite. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 114/75 mmHg, pulse is 93/min, respiratory rate is 14 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The surgical incision site is clean, dry, and intact without bulges. Abdominal examination is significant for diminished bowel sounds, tenderness over the right lower quadrant and right flank. The patient’s pain is increased with hip flexion against resistance. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm<sup>3</sup> and elevated CRP. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, right lower quadrant and flank pain, decreased appetite, elevated inflammatory markers, and positive psoas sign in the setting of a recent appendectomy suggests an intra-abdominal infection with extension to the psoas leading to abscess formation.

Psoas abscesses are caused by the accumulation of bacteria or pus within the psoas muscle, leading to inflammation and the formation of an abscess. They can occur via direct extension of an intra-abdominal infection, as is likely the case in this patient, or from hematologic seeding from a distant infection site. Patients usually present with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation, tachycardia with findings related to the localization of the abscess in the psoas muscle (e.g., pain with passive hip extension, pain with resisted hip flexion). Patients usually report a history of recent abdominal surgery, intra-abdominal infection, or abdominal trauma. Diagnosis is made by visualization of an abscess within the psoas muscle on an abdominopelvic CT scan and cultures sent to determine the underlying causative organism. Management consists of drainage and broad-spectrum antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

✅ Psoas abscess:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Renal colic:
Incorrect: Renal colic typically presents with sudden onset of waxing and waning severe flank pain radiating to the groin. The patient's recent appendectomy, fever, right lower quadrant pain induced by resisted hip flexion, and elevated inflammatory markers are more suggestive of an psoas abscess from extension of an abdominal infection.  
❌ Acute pyelonephritis:
Incorrect: Acute pyelonephritis can present with fever, flank pain, and elevated inflammatory markers. However, the patient's recent appendectomy, right lower quadrant abdominal pain, and positive psoas sign on physical examination are more suggestive of a psoas abscess.  
❌ Strangulated incisional hernia:
Incorrect: A strangulated incisional hernia may become ischemic and cause severe abdominal pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers in a patient with prior abdominal surgery. However, the absence of a palpable mass at the incision site makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Acute diverticulitis:
Incorrect: Acute diverticulitis usually presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers. The patient's recent appendectomy, right lower quadrant pain, and positive psoas sign are more consistent with a psoas abscess.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe sharp right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates toward the right lower thoracic back. The pain began that morning. The pain in the back is not improved or worsened with movement. Her symptoms are accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 150/78 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, pain is elicited upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this patient’s referred back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. These findings are concerning for acute cholecystitis. This patient’s pain in the right upper quadrant is due to irritation of the gallbladder and is considered somatic pain, which refers to pain located directly at the site of injury (e.g. pinprick on the skin).    
The patient is also experiencing referred pain to the back due to visceral referred pain. Referred pain is located away from or adjacent to the organ involved. Patients with acute cholecystitis often experience referred pain in the right lower thoracic spine, ribs, and right shoulder.   

Referred visceral pain occurs due to spatial and temporal summation of general visceral afferent (GVA) pain fibers. GVA pain fibers follow sympathetic nerves back to the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. As these preganglionic sympathetic fibers route to the spine and central nervous system (CNS), the CNS is unable to perceive the spatial location of the pain since it is lost at the level of the nerve ganglion. As a result, the pain is poorly localized and often referred to the dermatomal areas innervated by the same spinal level as the autonomic nerve supply. Consequently, when there is abdominal pathology, foregut pain is usually referred to the epigastrium, midgut to the umbilicus, and hindgut to the pelvis or hypogastrium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Greater thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lesser thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut
❌ Lumbar splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the hindgut
❌ Sacral nerve roots S2-4:
Incorrect: Sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4 provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe abdominal pain. The pain started approximately eight hours ago and was initially located in the periumbilical region. The pain increased in severity and became more localized to the lower right abdomen. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Using the image below, which of the following best identifies the location where this patient will be most tender with deep palpation?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with abdominal pain that originated in the periumbilical region and subsequently became more severe and migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. These findings are concerning for acute appendicitis.     

Appendicitis occurs due to obstruction and inflammation of the appendix. Initially, the visceral afferent fibers are stimulated and poorly localized abdominal pain or pain around the umbilicus is seen. As the appendix becomes more inflamed, the adjacent parietal peritoneum is irritated, and the pain becomes more localized to the right lower quadrant. On examination maximal tenderness with deep palpation at McBurney point will be seen. McBurney point is located two-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the right anterior superior iliac spine. Pain with deep palpation in this region is highly concerning for acute appendicitis and is called McBurney sign. Follow-up imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) should be obtained for further evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Location 1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location 2:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can initially manifest with referred pain in the periumbilical area, represented by location 2. However, the pain will often localize to the right lower abdominal quadrant. Maximal tenderness will be experienced with palpation at McBurney point, represented by Location 1, which corresponds to the base of the appendix  
❌ Location 3:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology.
❌ Location 4:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness in the suprapubic region indicated by Location 4 can be due to processes affecting the pelvic organs (e.g., cystitis, endometritis). In contrast, this patient’s history and physical examination are concerning for acute appendicitis, which may present at first with referred periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower abdominal quadrant. In acute appendicitis, maximal tenderness with deep palpation is typically seen at McBurney point, represented by Location 1.  
❌ Location 5:
Incorrect: Pain around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology. Left anterior superior iliac spine pain or tenderness is not typically seen with acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IV cholangiocarcinoma, for which she is receiving chemotherapy. Periodically, the patient develops ascites, for which abdominal paracentesis is performed. However, the patient was lost to follow-up. The patient is brought to the emergency department by her daughter with diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. On admission, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended and shifting dullness and a fluid wave are present. There is diffuse guarding with abdominal palpation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain in the setting of large-volume ascites due to end-stage liver failure caused by cholangiocarcinoma. These findings are concerning for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).    

SBP develops when enteric bacteria translocate from the intestinal lumen and infect the ascitic fluid. This occurs as a complication of liver disease due to increased permeability of the small intestinal wall and impaired immune defense mechanisms. SBP is a common cause of peritonitis which is defined as widespread inflammation of the inner abdomen wall and covering of the abdominal organs (the peritoneum). In addition to SBP, other causes of peritonitis include gastrointestinal tract perforation, infection due to surgical interventions, systemic infection, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Key signs and symptoms of peritonitis include fever, diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, abdominal rigidity, and paralytic ileus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of nitrogenous metabolites:
Incorrect: Accumulation of nitrogenous waste products, such as ammonia, can occur secondary to liver failure and may cause altered mental status or hepatic encephalopathy. However, hepatic encephalopathy does not cause fever and abdominal pain in the presence of ascites as seen in this case. A better explanation for this patient’s constellation of symptoms is SBP.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Large fluid shifts can be seen in patients with end-stage liver disease and they can result in symptoms of dehydration and even nausea and vomiting. However, dehydration would not account for the patient’s fever, abdominal pain, and ascites.  
❌ Tumor lysis syndrome:
Incorrect: Tumor lysis syndrome causes metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia), leading to acute kidney failure, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. This patient’s fever, abdominal pain and distension, and altered mental status are more likely caused by spontaneous bacterial peritonitis..  
❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Small bowel obstruction can lead to perforation and subsequently peritonitis. However given the presence of shifting dullness and fluid wave indicating ascites and the history of end-stage liver disease in this patient, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is the most likely cause of peritonitis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is seen on morning rounds reporting fevers, chills, and generalized abdominal pain. Five days ago, the patient sustained a gunshot wound to the abdomen that required exploratory laparotomy and resection of damaged portions of the bowel. The patient has not yet had a post-op return of bowel function. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals extreme abdominal tenderness to palpation and rebound tenderness that is most prominent in the lower abdomen. The abdomen is also mildly distended and bowel sounds are decreased. The surgical incision site and bullet wounds appear unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a leukocytes count of 17,000/mm3. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 cm abscess in the lower abdomen. The abscess is drained and fluid culture reveals methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria. Which of the following antibiotics should be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with peritonitis and an intra-abdominal abscess. Culture of the abscess fluid reveals methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus and anaerobic Gram-negative bacteria. Among the answer choices, the most appropriate treatment option is cefoxitin, a second-generation cephalosporin.

Second-generation cephalosporins include cefaclor, cefprozil, cefuroxime, cefotetan, and cefoxitin. This subgroup usually has slightly less activity against Gram-positive organisms when compared to first-generation cephalosporins. However, second-generation cephalosporins are more resistant to beta-lactamase and have greater Gram-negative coverage. They can be used to treat infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Serratia marcescens, Enterobacter aerogenes, and some Neisseria species. In addition, cefotetan and cefoxitin are the only cephalosporins that provide coverage against anaerobic bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis, which cause peritonitis and intra-abdominal abscesses.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Cefazolin:
Incorrect: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin. It does not have coverage against anaerobic bacteria such as Bacteroides fragilis.  
✅ Cefoxitin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Penicillin G:
Incorrect: Penicillin G is the first-line medication for the treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis and provides prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever. It can also be used to treat infections caused by organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Treponema pallidum. It is, however, not effective against Bacteroides fragilis.  
❌ Aztreonam:
Incorrect: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is effective against aerobic Gram-negative rods. It is not effective against Gram-positive bacteria or anaerobes.  
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It can be used in the management of Borrelia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia infections. However, it is not effective against Bacteroides fragilis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of several weeks of vague abdominal pain and increased fatigue. The pain is localized to the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and is non-radiating. He has not had chest pain, fever, or cough. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and a mildly distended soft abdomen. The liver edge is hard and is palpated 8 cm below the costal margin. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. Laboratory results are shown below. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. CT scan of the abdomen is shown. After an appropriate workup, a definitive diagnosis is established. The patient declines surgery and wishes to continue with pharmacological therapy. In addition to 5-fluorouracil, a topoisomerase I inhibitor is added to the regimen. Which of the following is the most likely agent that is added? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     8 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     8000/mm3    
 Platelet count       230,000/mm3    
 Mean corpuscular volume     68 μm3    
 Serum     
 Creatinine      0.9 g/dL    
 BUN     12 g/dL    
 Alanine aminotransferase      57 U/L    
 Aspartate aminotransferase      38 U/L    


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain and distention, microcytic anemia, positive fecal blood test, and hepatomegaly has multiple liver lesions on the CT scan, most likely due to undiagnosed colon cancer with metastasis to the liver. A combination of 5-fluorouracil and irinotecan (topoisomerase I inhibitor) represents one of the options of therapy for metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC).        

Topoisomerases are enzymes that relieve the DNA supercoiling that occurs during DNA replication as a result of the separation and unwinding of the DNA. Topoisomerase I makes single-stranded nicks to relieve negative supercoiling. Topoisomerase I inhibitors (e.g., topotecan and irinotecan) are synthetic derivatives of 20 (S)-camptothecin, a natural product from the Camptotheca acuminata tree. They bind to and stabilize a transient TOPO I–DNA complex, resulting in double-strand breakage and lethal DNA damage. A few of the important features of topotecan and irinotecan are tabulated above.   

Option Analysis

❌ Etoposide :
Incorrect: Etoposide is a topoisomerase II inhibitor that increases DNA degradation by arresting the cell cycle in G2 and S phases. Although it is used in the management of solid tumors (testicular and small cell lung cancer), it is not indicated in the management of metastatic colorectal cancer. 
✅ Irinotecan :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Topotecan :
Incorrect: Although topotecan is a topoisomerase I inhibitor, it is usually used in the management of ovarian and small cell lung cancer. It is not indicated in this patient. 
❌ Paclitaxel :
Incorrect: Paclitaxel is a microtubule inhibitor that hyper-stabilizes the polymerized microtubules in M phase so that the mitotic spindle cannot break down. It is usually indicated in the management of ovarian cancer. 
❌ Cladribine :
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by inhibiting DNA polymerase and by inducing DNA strand breaks. It, however, does not affect topoisomerase I and is mainly indicated in the management of hairy cell leukemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 1-month history of “feeling down” and a 5 kg unintentional weight loss. The patient reports vague abdominal pain radiating to the back and several episodes of tender erythematous, and palpable cord-like veins on the extremities. The patient has not had night sweats, fever, vomiting, dysphagia, change in urine or stool color, or change in bowel habits. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. Family history is significant for a parent who died from breast cancer at the age of 35. The patient has a 13-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 27 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 135/89 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination is significant for epigastric tenderness on palpation and a erythematous, tender, cord over the right lower extremity. Laboratory findings are significant for an elevated CA19-9. Which of the following studies should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of vague abdominal pain radiating to the back, “feeling down”, weight loss, migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome), and an elevated CA-19-9. Together, these findings are suggestive of pancreatic cancer in the body or tail of the pancreas. The most appropriate initial step in the evaluation of this patient with suspected pancreatic cancer without jaundice is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast.

Pancreatic cancer has an insidious onset and is often diagnosed at an advanced stage. The diagnostic workup for pancreatic cancer includes a combination of clinical, laboratory, and imaging tests. Initial laboratory evaluation should include an assay of serum aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, and CA 19-9 for establishing a baseline level for future monitoring. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected pancreatic cancer without signs or symptoms of obstruction. It can identify the tumor location, size, lymph node involvement, and abdominal/pelvic metastases. Other imaging modalities for evaluation include a transabdominal ultrasound and MRCP. If a pancreatic mass is identified on imaging, an endoscopic ultrasound or CT-guided biopsy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

After the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer is established, further imaging studies are performed including CT, MRI, or PET CT to determine the cancer stage and classification of resectability. If imaging demonstrates a tumor contained within the pancreas without metastases, it is amenable to resection. Tumors that have grown into nearby tissues, but have not yet developed distant metastases are considered “borderline” resectable. Tumors that involve, encase, or occlude a major peripancreatic vessel as well as those with distant metastases are considered unresectable.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings suggestive of pancreatic cancer including a 1-month history of vague abdominal pain, weight loss, migratory superficial thrombophlebitis, and an elevated CA19-9. CT is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating patients with suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy:
Incorrect:  Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is used in the evaluation of gastric malignancies, which can present with weight loss and vague abdominal pain. The presence of Trousseau syndrome, predisposing familial factor, and an elevated CA-19-9 makes the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer more likely.  
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is indicated in the management of patients with pancreatic cancer complicated by cholangitis and suspected pancreatic cancer with cholangitis. It is not used for the initial evaluation of suspected pancreatic cancer without cholangitis, as it is an invasive procedure associated with significant risks, including pancreatitis and bleeding. It should be reserved for diagnosis only in cases of obstructive cholangitis or when other imaging modalities are inconclusive.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is used in the evaluation of suspected colon cancer, not pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: During a tumor board meeting, the oncology team is asked to review the clinical therapy for a 63-year-old man who had a recently resected colonic tumor. Gross pathology shows that the tumor was large and nearly completely obstructing the colonic lumen. A recent PET scan conducted on this patient shows distant metastases which have penetrated the liver. The oncology team proposes starting the patient on the FOLFOX chemotherapy regimen. Before initiating therapy, the team proposes using a medication that will prime the patient’s immune system by increasing the immune visibility of the tumor. The patient is treated with cetuximab and is found to have little effect on metastatic tumor populations on imaging. A biopsy of the metastatic liver deposits is taken. A mutation in which of the following receptors is most likely?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a patient with a newly diagnosed stage IV colon cancer with metastases to the liver. Standard treatment for stage IV colon cancers includes either FOLFOX (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, and Oxaliplatin) or FOLFIRI (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, irinotecan) chemotherapy regimens. Before starting either of these chemotherapy regimens, it is now common to “prime” the patient’s immune system with targeted monoclonal antibodies, which help the patient’s immune system increase the immune visibility of tumor cells.    

Approximately 60-80% of cancer cells in colorectal tumors overexpress the EGFR receptor. Both  Cetuximab and Panitumumab are monoclonal antibody therapies targeted against the EGFR receptor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer and some head and neck tumors. Panitumumab is a human monoclonal antibody, whereas Cetuximab is a chimeric mouse monoclonal antibody. Both Cetuximab and Panitumumab have similar side effects, including rash, elevated LFTs, and diarrhea. Neither therapy is more efficacious in the treatment of colorectal cancer. A key difference between the two drugs is the role that cetuximab plays in immunological priming. Cetuximab has been shown to increase ADCC and other immunostimulatory activities such as cell maturation, T-cell recruitment to the tumor, increased antigen presentation, and cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. On the other hand, Panitumumab notably does not engage in cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. It does, however, engage in immune cytotoxicity at a much lower extent via neutrophil-driven ADCC. While it remains to be seen which of these drugs are superior in clinical efficacy, it’s clear that cetuximab has robust effects in modulating immune cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF:
Incorrect: This patient initially received cetuximab, which targets EGFR. A mutation in EGFR is most likely the cause of the tumor’s non-responsiveness to treatment.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: Mutations in HER2 occur in breast cancers, not colorectal cancers. 
❌ CD20 :
Incorrect: CD20 is a pan-B-Cell marker useful in diagnosing and treating leukemia. 
❌ KIT:
Incorrect: Mutations in KIT are common in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs)
✅ EGFR:
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever reaching 39.1°C (102.4°F), and right upper quadrant pain. The patient reports unintentional weight loss of 10 kg, jaundice, and dark urine over the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for chronic pancreatitis. BMI is 21 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 103/69 mmHg, pulse is 124/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96%. On physical examination, the patient appears ill, cachectic, and has right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis with left shift, elevated total and conjugated bilirubin, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals an ill-defined mass in the head of the pancreas, dilation of both the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct. IV access is established, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in the management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute cholangitis secondary to pancreatic cancer. This is confirmed with a CT of the abdomen showing a poorly defined mass in the head of the pancreas and dilation of both the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct. The best next step in management is to relieve the obstruction and obtain tissue for diagnosis with an emergency ERCP with biliary stenting.

A multidisciplinary approach is used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer consisting of a team of a medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, gastroenterologist, and surgeon. The management is complex and depends on the presence of signs of biliary obstruction and the extent of disease.

Patients with findings of biliary obstruction such as fever, severe jaundice, pruritus, altered mental status, or sepsis should be managed with stabilizing treatment, IV antibiotics, and emergency ERCP with biliary stenting or with percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement to relieve the obstruction.

Management of confirmed pancreatic cancer depends on the TNM staging of the disease and determination of whether or not the tumor is surgically resectable, borderline resectable, or unresectable. Patients with resectable tumors can be treated with a Whipple procedure (or modified version) for resection followed by possible adjuvant chemoradiation therapy depending on the extent of the disease on histopathology. Patients with borderline resectable pancreatic cancer should undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by reassessment with CT or MRI imaging. Patients with positive response to neoadjuvant chemoradiation are treated as surgically resectable. However, patients with minimal or no response to chemoradiation are managed as surgically unresectable. Patients who are found to have surgically unresectable pancreatic cancer have a very poor prognosis and are managed with chemoradiation therapy, supportive care, possible palliative care with pain medications, antiemetics, and ERCP with biliary stenting if obstruction occurs.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergency ERCP with biliary stenting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endoscopic-US guided biopsy:
Incorrect: Endoscopic-US guided biopsy may be used to provide a tissue diagnosis for pancreatic cancer. This patient has a fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and leukocytosis suggestive of acute cholangitis secondary to a mass in the head of the pancreas. Urgent ERCP with biliary stenting can be used to relieve the obstruction and confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Surgical excision of the mass:
Incorrect: Surgical excision of the mass is indicated for the management of patients with confirmed pancreatic cancer on histology without evidence of distant metastases or encasement/occlusion of major vessels. It is not indicated for the management of acute cholangitis in the setting of suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy is indicated for the management of patients with confirmed pancreatic cancer that is considered borderline resectable (local growth into nearby tissues without distant metastases). It is not indicated for the management of acute cholangitis in the setting of suspected pancreatic cancer.  
❌ CA-19-9 level measurement:
Incorrect: CA-19-9 levels are used to monitor treatment response and assess for future recurrences of pancreatic cancer and should be drawn in the case of suspected pancreatic cancer. However, they are not used to screen for pancreatic cancer or to make a definitive diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic for a routine colonoscopy. The patient is found to have a tumor located in the sigmoid colon, which is infiltrating into the descending large intestine. Biopsies of the tumor are taken on colonoscopy and are found to be aggressive colonic adenocarcinoma. Molecular studies are pending. PET scan shows metastatic disease reaching lymph nodes and the portal system. Which of the following is the strongest prognostic factor and target for treating this patient’s colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a colonic adenocarcinoma with metastasis to the liver and peripheral lymph nodes. While several mutations are associated with the development of metastatic colorectal cancer, only BRAF is highly prognostic and targetable. 

BRAF is a key intermediary in the choices listed MAPK signaling cascade, leading to the activation of ERK (see image). Some colorectal cancers can develop a V600E mutation of BRAF, driving high ERK signaling output independently. Similar mutations in BRAF are common in melanomas and some thyroid cancers and are associated with more aggressive phenotypes.  Therefore, inhibition of BRAF signaling is a key aspect of treatment in these cancers, as it significantly stifles cell proliferation in aberrant cells. BRAF inhibition is seldom used alone and is often combined with inhibition of complement pathways of tumorigenesis, including EGFR, MEK, PI3K, and Wnt pathways. BRAF inhibitors include encorafenib, dabrafenib, and vemurafenib. Side effects of these medications include the development of skin abnormalities such as kerato-acanthomas, diarrhea, fatigue, and arthralgias.    

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF mutations :
Incorrect: VEGF mutations are common in many solid cancers. They have little clinical significance in diagnosing and treating metastatic colon cancer.  
✅ BRAF V600E mutations :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age at initial diagnosis:
Incorrect: While age is an important aspect of colon cancer screening, age is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy 
❌ Family history of disease :
Incorrect: While family history is an important factor in colon cancer screening, it is not the strongest prognostic factor for patients who have metastatic colon cancer, nor is it targetable for therapy. 
❌ Microsatellite instability :
Incorrect: Microsatellite instability (MSI) is associated with colon cancer and BRAF mutations; however, prognostically, having a BRAF mutation is more prognostically significant than MSI.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with a 2-month history of jaundice and nausea. He also reports 9 kg weight loss, fatigue, and a depressed mood for the past 3 months. He has not had fevers, abdominal pain, vomiting, or pruritus. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus diagnosed 6 months ago. The patient has a 20-pack year smoking history. Family history is significant for a parent who died from colon cancer at the age of 64. BMI is 21 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 109/71 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination is significant for jaundice, and mild epigastric pain on deep palpation of the abdomen. Which of the following is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Golden brown rings at the periphery of the cornea seen on slit lamp examination
Right upper quadrant abdominal pain on palpation during inspiration
Red spider-like lesions on skin examination

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-month history of jaundice, nausea, weight loss, fatigue, depressed mood, and new-onset diabetes mellitus. These findings suggest a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, resulting in incomplete obstruction and dilation of the common bile duct. The most likely additional finding on physical examination would be the presence of a palpable distended non-tender gallbladder, known as Courvoisier sign, which can be a sign of pancreatic or biliary malignancy.

Pancreatic cancer constitutes one of the leading causes of cancer-related mortality due to its insidious onset. It is divided into exocrine and endocrine tumors with exocrine pancreatic adenocarcinoma being the most common type. Risk factors can be divided into hereditary (e.g., first-line relative with a history of pancreatic cancer, hereditary pancreatitis, germ-line mutations) and environmental causes (e.g., cigarette smoking, diabetes mellitus, chronic pancreatitis).

Tumors in the head of the pancreas typically present with findings related to obstruction of the common bile duct (e.g., jaundice, steatorrhea, acute cholangitis, Courvoisier sign) and may not present with abdominal pain (painless jaundice). Tumors in the body and tail of the pancreas present with findings related to tumor invasion and splanchnic innervation of the body and tail (e.g., epigastric pain radiating to the back). Other nonspecific findings may be present in a patient with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss, fatigue, anorexia, or depression. Additional findings include new-onset diabetes mellitus secondary to pancreatic dysfunction, Trousseau syndrome (migratory thrombophlebitis), and findings related to metastasis (e.g., hepatomegaly, ascites, lymphadenopathy).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Palpable, non-tender gallbladder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bilateral gynecomastia:
Incorrect: Bilateral gynecomastia is often seen in patients with cirrhosis, which can present with jaundice, weight loss, and fatigue. The absence of predisposing risk factors, like alcohol use disorder or hepatitis, makes the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer the more likely cause of jaundice, weight loss, and nausea in this patient.  
❌ Golden brown rings at the periphery of the cornea seen on slit lamp examination:
Incorrect: Kayser-Fleischer rings (golden-brown rings at the periphery of the cornea seen on slit lamp examination) are seen in patients with Wilson disease, which is a genetic disorder resulting in copper accumulation in the liver with subsequent liver damage. This patient likely has pancreatic cancer as the cause of jaundice, weight loss, and new-onset diabetes.  
❌ Right upper quadrant abdominal pain on palpation during inspiration:
Incorrect: A positive Murphy sign, characterized by the presence of right upper quadrant pain upon palpation during inspiration, may indicate the presence of cholecystitis and an inflamed gallbladder. This patient has no fever or right upper quadrant pain to suggest cholecystitis.  
❌ Red spider-like lesions on skin examination:
Incorrect: Spider angiomas are red, spider-like lesions on the skin that are seen in patients with cirrhosis, and are caused by hyperestrinism. While cirrhosis can present with jaundice, weight loss, and fatigue, the absence of predisposing risk factors (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C, alcohol), and the presence of new-onset diabetes mellitus makes the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer more likely.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of early satiety and bloating for the past several weeks. He also reports sporadic bouts of hematemesis. He reports that over this same period, he has lost 11-lb due to decreased appetite. The patient has no significant past medical history. CT shows a 2 X 2 cm mass in the antrum of the stomach. Upper endoscopy is performed, and a mass is visualized in the stomach. An excisional biopsy was taken. On pathology, the patient is found to have a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Molecular pathology reveals a mutation in KIT. Which of the following is the best therapeutic intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presented with symptoms of early satiety, bloating, and weight loss, was found to have a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) with a KIT mutation. The ideal therapy for this patient would be to target this mutation selectively. Only imatinib, a small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor, does this of the listed answer choices.

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor commonly used for chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphocytic leukemia, and some types of GISTs. Imatinib functions by inhibiting the kinase domain of the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase. Tyrosine kinases are enzymes responsible for signal transduction cascades responsible for cell proliferation. Inhibition of tyrosine kinases selectively inhibits the proliferation of cancers that overexpress them. The KIT kinase is structurally similar to the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase. This prompted a clinical trial immediately to investigate the use of imatinib in the treatment of KIT tumors, such as GISTs. Now, using imatinib is established as first-line therapy in treating metastatic GIST. A common side effect of imatinib therapy is fluid retention, hepatotoxicity, and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome. Other tyrosine kinase inhibitors targeting BCR-ABL include nilotinib, bosutinib, ponatinib, and afatinib, which are marketed as second-line therapeutic agents.    

Option Analysis

❌ Cetuximab :
Incorrect: Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody targeting EGFR. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
❌ Bevacizumab :
Incorrect: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting VEGF-A. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
✅ Imatinib :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alemtuzumab :
Incorrect: Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting CD52. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
❌ Hydroxyurea :
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used to treat melanoma and treatment-resistant CML. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to her physician after being diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma. She is being treated with rituximab. Based on its naming convention, what kind of monoclonal antibody is rituximab?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibodies are a collection of relatively new classes of therapeutic biologic agents. As the name suggests, monoclonal antibodies are antibodies created from a single parent cell exogenously. They bind to specific protein targets on the extracellular cell membrane of tumors or virus-ridden cells. The parent cell where the antibody was created may vary, with some being created in different mammalian cells such as hamsters, primates, mice, etc. Furthermore, antibodies can be chimeric, fuzing variable regions from one species like a mouse, with another such as humans. While the suffix of all monoclonal antibodies ends with “-mab”, substems precede the suffix that describes the origin of the drug (see table below). In the case of rituximab, the “xi” substem shows that this agent is a chimeric monoclonal antibody.  

Option Analysis

❌ Primate :
Incorrect: Primate monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-i-.” 
❌ Mouse :
Incorrect: Mouse monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-o-.”  
❌ Hamster :
Incorrect: Hamster monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-e-.” 
❌ Humanized :
Incorrect: Humanized monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-zu.” 
✅ Chimeric  :
Correct: see main explanation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the clinic with episodic lower abdominal discomfort, bloating, and hematochezia for 4 months. She has not had diarrhea and the amount of stool she passes with each bowel movement has been smaller than usual. She reports weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lbs) over the past 4 months. Her appetite has remained unchanged, but she feels "full" earlier than usual after starting meals. Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) managed with omeprazole and irritable bowel syndrome diagnosed in her 30s. Family history is positive for endometrial cancer in her mother at the age of 32. Her diet is significant for high consumption of dairy products. Body mass index (BMI) is 20 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Abdominal examination shows mild distention with hyperactive bowel sounds and mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant without palpable masses. Digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals stool with blood in it and no evidence of hemorrhoids or fissures. Laboratory results are significant for a hemoglobin of 10.3 g/dL, and an MCV of 72 fl. Which of the following features would most significantly increase this patient’s risk for the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Family history of endometrial cancer at an early age
Chronic use of proton pump inhibitors (PPI)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with episodic lower abdominal discomfort, bloating, early satiety, weight loss, change in stool caliber, hematochezia, and microcytic anemia. This clinical presentation is highly suggestive of colorectal cancer (CRC). Multiple risk factors can contribute to the development of CRC. In this patient, family history of endometrial cancer in a first-degree relative at an early age raises the possibility of Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer or HNPCC).

Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a high risk of developing CRC, endometrial cancer, and ovarian cancer. Defective DNA mismatch repair genes, predominantly MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2, lead to a rapid accumulation of errors in the DNA, especially in areas known as microsatellites. These genetic errors accelerate the progression from adenoma to carcinoma in the colon.

Signs and symptoms associated with CRC can vary based on the location of the tumor. Right-sided (proximal) colon tumors, encompassing the cecum to the right half of the transverse colon, lead to occult blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia. In contrast, left-sided (distal) tumors, involving the left transverse colon to the sigmoid, frequently cause changes in bowel habits, colicky abdominal pain, and sometimes blood-streaked stool. Tumors located in the rectum may produce symptoms of tenesmus, rectal bleeding, and stool caliber changes.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of endometrial cancer at an early age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS):
Incorrect: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional gastrointestinal disorder. While its symptoms can mimic those seen in colorectal cancer, IBS itself does not increase the risk of developing colorectal cancer.  
❌ Body mass index (BMI) <21 kg/m2  :
Incorrect: A low BMI can be seen in colorectal cancer due to cancer-related weight loss. However, having a low BMI is not a risk factor for developing CRC. Conversely, obesity is a recognized risk factor for colorectal cancer.  
❌ Chronic use of proton pump inhibitors (PPI)  :
Incorrect: Chronic use of PPIs like omeprazole has been associated with various gastrointestinal problems including Clostridium difficile infection, atrophic gastritis, malabsorption of minerals and vitamins, and an increased risk of developing gastric polyps. It has not been directly correlated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.  
❌ Diet high in dairy:
Incorrect: High dairy consumption has been suggested to have a protective effect against colorectal cancer due to its calcium content. Conversely, a diet high in red and processed meats is recognized as a risk factor for colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine checkup. She has been feeling tired over the past few months. She also reports constipation which is new for her. She has not had abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes managed with metformin and a hysterectomy 10 years ago for fibroids. Family history is significant for colon cancer in her maternal aunt at the age of 71. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and unremarkable abdominal findings. Digital rectal examination shows no hemorrhoids or anal fissures. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, and an MCV of 71 fl. Iron studies indicate low serum iron, low ferritin, and increased total iron-binding capacity. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous iron administration and re-evaluation in 3 months

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation is consistent with iron-deficiency anemia, as indicated by the low hemoglobin, low MCV, low serum iron, and low ferritin levels. In postmenopausal women, the most common cause of iron-deficiency anemia is gastrointestinal blood loss. Given her age, family history of colon cancer, and symptoms of fatigue and constipation, colorectal cancer (CRC) should be ruled out as a source of occult bleeding. Colonoscopy serves as the gold standard for diagnosis and evaluation of suspected CRC. It allows for visualization of the entire colon and rectum, biopsy of suspicious lesions, and removal of polyps.

On colonoscopy, distinctive indicators of colon cancer include irregularly raised masses or fungating growths that can constrict the colon's lumen; and polyps, especially adenomatous ones that have a high potential to become malignant. The morphology of polyps (i.e. sessile or pedunculated) can indicate malignancy risk. Additionally, ulcers with characteristic raised, uneven edges can be indicative of CRC. One of the most recognizable signs is the "apple-core" or "napkin-ring" lesion, typically representing annular constricting tumors frequently observed in the descending or sigmoid colon. The colonoscopy findings seen in colon cancer are the same as those seen with rectal cancer. Masses will be endoluminal, exophytic, and polypoid, with possible bleeding and necrosis, and malignant cells will be seen on biopsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fecal immunochemical test (FIT)  :
Incorrect: This patient with fatigue, change in bowel habits, and microcytic anemia is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). The FIT test can detect occult blood in the stool, which can be a sign of CRC. While less invasive than a colonoscopy, it doesn't allow for direct visualization or biopsy of lesions. A direct examination via colonoscopy is more appropriate in this patient to diagnose CRC.  
❌ Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). CEA is a tumor marker that may be elevated in CRC. However, it's not used for screening or initial diagnosis due to its low sensitivity and specificity. It is used for monitoring disease progression or recurrence in patients already diagnosed with CRC.  
❌ Intravenous iron administration and re-evaluation in 3 months:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). Treating the anemia without investigating its cause would be inappropriate, especially given the patient's age, family, and clinical findings.  
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having colorectal cancer (CRC). A barium enema may show "apple core" or "napkin ring" lesions in cases of colon cancer, which represent circumferential growths that constrict the lumen of the colon. However, barium enema is less sensitive than a colonoscopy and doesn't allow for biopsy or polyp removal.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent rectal bleeding and recent unintentional weight loss of 10 kg (22 lbs). He reports no other significant gastrointestinal symptoms. His past medical history includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 75. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is significant for pallor. Digital rectal examination reveals blood without evidence of fissures or hemorrhoids. A colonoscopy is performed, showing a 4 cm ulcerating mass in the sigmoid colon, with biopsy confirming adenocarcinoma. A subsequent abdominal CT demonstrates a solitary 3 cm lesion in the right lobe of the liver. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Partial colectomy, partial hepatectomy, and adjuvant chemotherapy
Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy

questions.solution:
The patient's biopsy confirming adenocarcinoma and abdominal CT findings indicate that this patient has colorectal cancer with an isolated liver metastasis. With isolated liver metastases, surgical resection of both the primary tumor (partial colectomy) and the hepatic lesion (partial hepatectomy), followed by adjuvant chemotherapy is the recommended treatment strategy.

Patients with non-metastatic colorectal cancer with small primary tumors can be treated with endoscopic transanal excision. More advanced tumors necessitate neoadjuvant therapy, the efficacy of which is subsequently assessed via proctoscopy and MRI. If a positive therapeutic response is observed, then surgical resection of the tumor can follow. If there are non-clear margins or lymphatic involvement adjuvant chemotherapy should be given. In cases with distant metastases, therapeutic decisions become more complex. Patients with solitary hepatic or pulmonary metastases may qualify for initial surgical removal of the colorectal tumor and the metastatic lesion. For inoperable cases, chemotherapy is recommended initially. Post-chemotherapeutic tumor restaging informs the subsequent therapeutic. A marked reduction in metastatic burden suggests a successful chemotherapeutic response and opens the possibility for surgical intervention. However, no response or an inadequate response indicates the need to shift to second-line chemotherapeutic agents or immunotherapeutic modalities, complemented by palliative care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Partial colectomy, partial hepatectomy, and adjuvant chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Systemic chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Systemic chemotherapy is used to treat metastatic colorectal cancer with multiple unresectable distal mets. When a solitary liver metastasis is present, a combination of surgical resection of the primary tumor and the liver lesion is often the optimal initial approach.  
❌ Neoadjuvant chemotherapy and partial colectomy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used to shrink the size of tumors before surgery. This might prove beneficial for locally advanced tumors, but patients with resectable primary tumors and resectable isolated liver metastases may first have surgery.  
❌ Partial colectomy and adjuvant chemotherapy:
Incorrect: While a partial colectomy addresses the primary tumor, the presence of liver metastasis also requires urgent intervention. Adjuvant chemotherapy is used post-operatively to eradicate remaining microscopic disease, but an isolated resectable liver metastasis should be removed surgically first.  
❌ Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy:
Incorrect: Systemic chemotherapy and targeted liver radiotherapy can be used to treat liver metastases, but the primary tumor should be removed with partial colectomy. Radiotherapy can be a valuable adjunct for liver metastases, especially when surgical resection is not feasible; however, in cases with a solitary liver metastatic lesion, surgical intervention is the preferred approach.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and discomfort during bowel movements for the past five weeks. She has not had recent weight loss, changes in bowel habits, or abdominal pain. The patient has a history of receptive anal intercourse with multiple partners over the past ten years. The patient’s father died from colon cancer at the age of 60 years. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a hard fixed mass palpated in the anal canal. Inguinal lymphadenopathy is present bilaterally. Which of the following would be most associated with a malignant cause of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Family history of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
Family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
History of recent travel to a tropical region

questions.solution:
This patient with rectal bleeding, anal pain, and a hard fixed anal mass on digital rectal exam most likely has anal cancer. Anal cancer is a malignancy of the anal canal or perianal area. The two main subtypes of anal cancer are squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) which is the most common type, and adenocarcinoma. Although rare, the incidence of anal cancer has been increasing over the last two decades likely due to the spread of human papillomavirus (HPV) which is the primary cause of anal SCC. A history of anogenital warts, which HPV causes, is a significant risk factor for the development of anal cancer.

Patients with suspected anal cancer should have a thorough history taken to evaluate for risk factors. Anal cancer is strongly associated with a history of HPV infection (anal, cervical, vaginal, vulvar), particularly the high-risk strains HPV 16 and 18. HPV-related anal cancers often arise from precursor lesions, and individuals with a history of anogenital warts are at increased risk of developing these lesions and subsequently anal cancer. HPV is transmitted sexually therefore a high lifetime number of sexual partners, as well as receptive anal intercourse, increase the likelihood of contracting the virus and developing anal cancer. Patients who are immunocompromised, including those living with HIV infection, are also at an increased risk for anal cancer, and cigarette smoking increases the risk.

Patients may present with anal pain, rectal bleeding, and a sensation of a mass within or around the anus. On digital rectal exam (DRE) the clinician may note a palpable perianal or anal mass, which can be firm, fixed, or ulcerated.
